posts.cooked: private void configureButtonBindings() { //Driver Buttons zeroGyro.whenPressed(new InstantCommand(() â†’ s_Swerve.zeroGyro())); } "The method whenPressed(Command) from the type Button is deprecated. " what can i use instead of it?

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: .onTrue Iâ€™m pretty sure if you hover over whenPressed in wpilib vscode itâ€™ll tell you what to use. I donâ€™t have a wpilib 23 install on this computer though so I canâ€™t check.

posts.name: Christian Femia
posts.cooked:
Depending on what controller you are using, it may be best to switch your zeroGyro Button object to a Trigger Object (such as CommandXboxController ), since the Button Class has been deprecated.

Using the CommandXboxController , you can do the following: driverController.back().onTrue(new InstantCommand(() â†’ s_Swerve.zeroGyro()));

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
First you should put your code between three ticks (the symbol to left of the 1 key in your keyboard) so it will be easier to read. If you include the language name after the first ``` the code will also be syntax-highlighted:

The first problem I see is where you define driver (which you should also give a more descriptive name because â€œdriverâ€ usually means something else in computers). You define it as Joystick but then create Xbox buttons from it. So the first thing to fix is driver to be an XboxController . You could also use the better version which is CommandXboxController . This class provides factory methods returning a Trigger for each button. There is a bit more explanation in the docs .

Now, once you have a Trigger instead of a JoystickButton , you can use onTrue() as Christian suggested. The only change I offered is to refactor new InstantCommand(() -> s_Swerve.zeroGyro()) into new InstantCommand(s_Swerve::zeroGyro) . Because zeroGyro() takes no arguments, you can use here a method reference which is a bit nicer and shorter than a â€œregularâ€ lambda expression.
